questions.question:
Question 1: Effect of acute ethanol consumption is inhibitory on which of the following ligand-gated ion 
channels?
questions.explanation:
The effect of acute ethanol consumption is inhibitory on NMDA receptor-operated channels. Effects of acute ethanol on ion channels: Enhancement • GABA-A receptor-operated channels • Glycine receptor-operated channels • Nicotinic ACh receptor-operated channels • 5HT3 receptor-operated channels • G protein-coupled inwardly rectifying K+ channels • Large conductance, Ca2+/ voltage-activated K+ channels Inhibition • NMDA receptor-operated channels 400 
Sold by @itachibot • Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels

questions.question:
Question 2: The black-outs associated with high levels of ethanol can be attributed to its action on which 
of the following receptors?
questions.explanation:
Blackouts are periods of memory loss that occur with high ethanol consumption and may result 
from the ability of ethanol to inhibit the action of glutamate on NMDA receptors. NMDA receptor is implicated in many aspects of cognitive function including learning and 
memory.

questions.question:
Question 3: Ethanol ingestion results in enhanced diuresis. What is the most probable mechanism 
causing this?

options.a: Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules
options.b: Stimulation of ADH action in collecting tubules
options.c: Stimulation of ADH release from pituitary gland
options.d: Inhibition of ADH release from pituitary gland

questions.explanation:
Ethanol inhibits the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)/ vasopressin from the posterior 
pituitary gland. This results in enhanced diuresis observed with ethanol ingestion. Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules is not the mechanism by which alcohol induces 
diuresis. Stimulation of ADH release or action will have an antidiuretic action.

questions.question: Question 4: What effect does acute consumption of ethanol have on cytochrome enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Acute consumption of ethanol inhibits the function of several cytochrome enzymes that are 
involved in the metabolism of drugs. CYP2E1 is one of the isoenzymes that is specifically 
inhibited. Chronic consumption of alcohol causes induction of cytochrome enzymes, particularly CYP2E1, 
increasing the rate of metabolism of drugs dependent on CYP2E1 for metabolism.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor that you would prescribe for 
the pharmacological management of a patient addicted to alcohol?
questions.explanation:
Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde 
dehydrogenase. Ethanol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of 
acetaldehyde. Increased acetaldehyde levels can cause flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing 
pain in the head and neck, and other aversive reactions. Disulfiram is indicated in alcohol deaddiction maintenance therapy. Option 1: Fomepizole is an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase. Option 3: Acamprosate is an NMDA receptor antagonist with modest GABA-A receptor agonistic 
activity. Option 4: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics. 401 
Sold by @itachibot Option 5: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that can be used to treat acute alcohol withdrawal 
and anxiety.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 51-year-old diabetic patient presents to your OPD with severe restlessness, palpitations, 
flushing, and sweating. His medication history includes OHAs and an antibiotic that was 
started 3 days back. On enquiring, he admits that he consumed two shots of whiskey after 
taking his medications. Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause similar effects?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Metformin is not 
associated with a disulfiram-like reaction following alcohol ingestion. Disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol ingestion is seen with the following drugs: • Metronidazole • 1st generation sulfonylureas like chlorpropamide • Cephalosporins like cefoperazone, cefamandole • Griseofulvin • Procarbazine

questions.question:
Question 7: A 40-year-old man with alcohol dependence is referred to a rehabilitation center for 
deaddiction. Which of the following drugs would you not prescribe for maintenance of 
deaddiction?
questions.explanation:
Morphine, an opioid receptor agonist, is not indicated for alcohol deaddiction maintenance. 
Opioid receptor antagonist is indicated for this condition. Drugs approved for the maintenance therapy and to prevent relapse: • Naltrexone: It is an orally active opioid receptor antagonist. • Acamprosate: An NMDA receptor antagonist with modest GABA-A receptor agonistic activity. • Disulfiram: A deterrent drug that works by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following anti-epileptics is effective in maintaining abstinence in a patient 
undergoing treatment for alcohol deaddiction?
questions.explanation:
Topiramate has shown efficacy in maintaining abstinence and reducing craving in chronic 
alcoholism. Though effective, topiramate is not yet approved for use in alcohol deaddiction maintenance. It is 
used off-label for this indication. Ondansetron and baclofen are other drugs that are found to be effective but not yet approved for 
this use.

questions.question:
Question 9: A young man presented to the ER with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of 
vision after he consumed a bottle of illicit liquor. His ABG shows a high anion gap metabolic 
acidosis. Which of the following statements would be incorrect regarding his management?

options.b: Intravenous ethanol is an alternative to fomepizole
options.d: Folinic acid is also used in treatment

questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture and labs are suggestive of accidental methanol toxicity. Hemodialysis is 
used in severe cases of methanol toxicity. 402 
Sold by @itachibot A serum methanol concentration greater than 50 mg/dl is serious enough to consider 
hemodialysis. It can be used to remove both methanol and its toxic metabolite formic acid from 
the blood. Option A: Fomepizole, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, is administered intravenously in 
methanol toxicity. It acts by inhibiting the formation of formic acid. Option B: Intravenous ethanol is an alternative to fomepizole. It has a higher affinity to alcohol 
dehydrogenase than methanol. Thus, saturation of ADH enzymes results in less formation of toxic 
formic acid. Option D: Folate-dependent systems are responsible for the oxidation of formic acid to CO2. Both 
folinic and folic acid are often administered during methanol toxicity but the exact benefit is yet to 
be determined. Note: Ethanol is given intravenously in the management of methanol and ethylene glycol 
poisoning.

questions.question:
Question 10: How is the administration of ethanol going to help in the management of methanol 
poisoning?

options.b: Ethanol slows down metabolism of methanol
options.c: Ethanol reacts with methanol to form an inactive metabolite
options.d: Ethanol reverses the actions of methanol

questions.explanation:
Administration of ethanol slows down the metabolism of methanol. Ethanol has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Formic acid is the metabolite of methanol which is highly toxic. Therefore, slowing down the 
metabolism of methanol reduces its toxic effects.

questions.question:
Question 11: A middle-aged man undergoing treatment for alcohol deaddiction was started on disulfiram. 
Which of the following statements is true regarding this drug?
questions.explanation:
Alcohol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of 
acetaldehyde. This can cause aversive reactions resulting in flushing, pulsating headache, 
throbbing pain in the head and neck, nausea, vomiting, rashes, respiratory difficulties, chest pain, 
and autonomic manifestations. Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde 
dehydrogenase. It is used in behavioral modification for alcohol de-addiction. Option B: The principle of action is aversive conditioning (not anti-craving). Option C: Disulfiram can be given only to highly motivated individuals. It should not be 
administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours. Option D: The disulfiram-alcohol reaction may persist as long as 14 days after the last dose of 
disulfiram. 403
